description:
The moment is now—AMD RDNA™ 4 graphics cards have arrived, delivering breakthrough performance to every battle, mission, and victory empowering you to make every play count. Experience a new era of gaming innovation with AMD.

Discover more: https://www.amd.com/en/products/graphics/desktops/radeon.html

00:06 Intro - AMD's 25-year commitment to gaming
04:34 RDNA 4 Architecture - A deep dive into AMD's latest graphics architecture
11:11 Toy Shop Demo - A glimpse into the future of gaming visuals
13:47 Software Innovations - Enhancing the gaming experience with software
17:53 FSR 4 - Introducing AMD's new machine learning powered upscaling
21:40 Radeon RX 9000 Series - Unveiling the new graphics cards
23:16 RX 9070 & 9070 XT - Details on performance, pricing, and availability
28:55 Crimson Desert - A sneak peek at the upcoming game
31:12 Availability & Outro - When and where to buy the new cards

comments.text:
AMD’s stagnant GPUs and their reliance on FSR, while pushing for raw, bleeding-edge power.
AMD’s GPUs? Old news. The 7900 XTX smoked them, but that was ages ago—over three years, and we’re in 2025 with nothing new. The 9700 XT? A weaker 7900 XTX rehash. Lame. AMD’s been coasting, and it shows.

What they need: True raw power. Think 32 GB VRAM, 30–50% stronger than the 7900 XTX, native 4K/8K—no FSR or DLSS crutches. FSR’s a cop-out, like AMD’s tying their own hands. Tech’s getting lazy, and it’s slowing everything down.

The 7900 XTX proved AMD can nearly catch NVIDIA. If they’d go all-in on bleeding-edge—4K at 200 FPS, pure native—they’d build cheaper, killer GPUs for the future. But chasing fake frames? That’s a money pit, stalling the halo products they’ve already dragged their feet on.

Gamers and creators deserve better. We want competition—GPUs that crush 4K/8K without overheating or leaning on FSR. Full creative freedom. Next-gen gaming, no compromises.

comments.text:
Gamers and creators deserve AMD GPUs that dominate 4K to 8K gaming at 250 FPS—natively, without leaning on FSR or AI-generated frames. FSR’s “fake” frames might prop up weaker cards, but they’re a roadblock to real GPU innovation. By relying on upscaling, AMD risks growing complacent, delaying the powerful, next-gen hardware we’re starving for. AI frame generation? That’s a distant dream, 5–10 years off, and we’re not waiting that long.

What we demand is a Halo Card—a true next-gen beast that sets the standard. Picture this: 28 or 32 GB of VRAM, at least 50% more power than the 7900 XTX, built from the ground up as a gaming juggernaut and a hybrid powerhouse for game developers and content creators. This isn’t just a wish—it’s what AMD can deliver if they ditch the crutches of FSR and frame generation.

We’re done with fake frames and half-steps. We want 2026/27-level technology now—bleeding-edge hardware that redefines what’s possible. AMD has the talent and the tools; if they poured more time and development into raw power instead of software tricks, we’d already have the true next-gen GPU we’ve been begging for. Let’s make it happen!

comments.text: I saw plenty of ghosting and ray tracing lag and noise in the toy shop demonstration. Ideally ray tracing isn't tied to ML as ML always botches the job vs the original image. Lots of shimmering especially on the counter. Ideally you dont have to do a de-noising pass at all. Even NVIDIA's denoisers botch the job and the 5090 still has ray tracing lag even with DLSS. I dont even us AA in most titles (some games tie other features to AA unfortunately usually console ports) because even the denoisers in AA will reduce detail significantly and create noticeable noise and ghosting (also I game at 4k so I can turn that stuff off and not have a problem unless a game uses low quality assets / textures). Plenty of noticeable motion blur in BO6 with FSR. Also i AA is generally deprecated at 4k as long as a game has high quality textures and assets. I still hope to see a 90 class card. Even tho you are claiming an uplift in creator type workloads the uplift can still be higher and those workloads still require a significant amount of vRAM. Also can we just dump the HDMI port on the GPU's and just include a DP to HDMI dongle in the box. HDMI ports can only produce a single image can even split to extended displays... Useless when DP can split to multiple extended HDMI displays...

comments.text:
RDNA 1 was really a revolution, the shaders became stronger
and the pipeline was nice and short giving us good raster performance. 

"kinda what happend between maxwell and pascall on the competitor side" 

With this RDNA 4, AMD is giving us similar raster as the 7900 GRE / XT but with less of everything
Less Rops, Less TMU's, Less Shaders, 

While Nvidia is now at its end of its architecture, giant long pipeline, 
power hungry, needs more Rops, TMU's, Shaders and 700 mhz to win or loose
by 2 to 5% to its predecessor "comparing 5080 to 4080 here" 

So while its competitor has to increase shader, rop, tmu counts to beat its own
previous generation, AMD is giving us half a die, clearly holding back, 
there is more space on this die..
If they wanted to fill that up I wonder just what could come out. 

To bad their afraid of being split apart in to ATi due to regulations, its why
there is no 9900 XTX I think, double this and even path and raytracing would
be far superior to a 5090 by a mile, but you would need 400 watts, Don't think they want
us to use more cables. 

This shrinking and optimizing their architecture is still very smart. It will
pay dividends for the future, especially for their APU division, being able
to do more with less of everything, means smaller and more power efficient gpu's
for portable or other market segments.

comments.text:
While on the one hand I understand the point in comparing the RX 9070 and RX 9070 XT to the RX 7900 GRE allows them to showcase a consistent performance uplift.
It should be noted that the RX 7900 GRE is little more than a "Theoretical" GPU outside of China., as it's almost impossible to buy anywhere.

With this said., in terms of generational performance improvement... assuming the benchmarks are accurate, we are finally seeing classic generational performance improvement.
The RX 9070 with 56CU is close to the RX 7700 XT which has 54CU., and in terms of performance we're looking at a 1.6x Performance Improvement... although this said this is where the price is less "impressive" as MSRP between the two the RX 7700 XT was $449 Vs. the RX 9070 at $549.

Same is true for the RX 9070 XT with 64CU, which is close to the RX 7800 XT which has 60CU... again, we're looking at ~1.5x Performance Improvement., but once again it should be noted the MSRP of $499 Vs. $599.

Don't get me wrong here., as the RX 9070 and RX 9070 XT are delivering (Rasterisation wise) on-par performance to the RX 7900 XT (MSRP $899 / CRP $649) and RX 7900 XTX (MSRP $999 / CRP $849)., while in terms of RT we can only really compare to the RTX 4070 TI SUPER and RTX 4080 SUPER; but still these only look like "Good Value" when we're comparing either to the Higher-End RX 7000 Series (which they're similar performance to) or the RTX 50 Series they're directly competing with (RTX 5070 / $549, RTX 5070 TI / $749); but those are disgustingly over-priced. 

I mean this still ends up looking like a "Win" for AMD here., but honestly... given they now have a clear performance advantage per Core., to lean heavily into that with much more aggressive pricing... either by pricing on-par with the RX 7700 XT ($449) and RX 7800 XT ($499) or even better the RX 7700 ($379) and RX 7700 XT ($449) 

Remember in terms of inflation., this is where the mainstream Graphics Cards should be... the $280 - 450 Bracket. 
And at those prices... these would go from a "Good" to "Impressive" generational improvement; and more than this., AMD (as was the case with Ryzen) would become the MUST HAVE that entirely changes the landscape.

As noted, assuming these performance figures are accurate; this is still a "Win" for Team Red; but given AMD only have ~12% of the Graphics (Gaming) Market... really given performance is clearly there now., they should be pricing to try to be pushing for a more 50/50 Market Share., as this will break NVIDIA' Monopoly that they've had for 25 years. 
It would also allow AMD to start pressuring or setting the direction of GPU Technology; to prevent a repeat of GCN.
Keep in mind GCN wasn't a bad Architecture by any stretch of the imagination... the issue was it was designed & developed with Low-Level Graphics APIs in mind... NVIDIA were able to use their monopoly over the industry to retard support for such for almost 5 years (2 Generations) until they were ready to release something competitive; all of which time AMD was struggling in terms of Fund because they kept losing market share as they were simply not competitive; and by the time they were., they had been forced to do little more than refinements on what was then a 5-6 year old architecture.
That's when NVIDIA introduced Ray Tracing as to prevent AMD from gaining any real traction with LLVM Graphics. 

Realistically right now... AMD have NVIDIA by the short-and-curlies. All they need to do is pressure them much more with aggressive pricing; and we could be looking at a REAL competitive environment for Graphics; which is better not just for AMD but the Consumers as well.

comments.text: I've been playing Diablo 4 on a 4k monitor for half a year, medium/high settings, between 50-80fps. I'm using the RDNA3 generation from a minipc (Minisforum brand). Am I satisfied? Yes. I'm very satisfied from several points of view: the price (350€), the maximum consumption of the pc (60-70w), the fact that I can hold two monitors. Yes, this technology so far was not 100% perfect but the value for price/consumption is extraordinarily low. It's what I was looking for. By the way, I always travel with a monitor (4k or fullHD and Minisforum or Mac Mini M2). The best choices in the last year. I can play and edit Lightroom/Photoshop, almost wherever I am. Both systems without monitors cost me 1000€ peripherals included. Come with questions. This is the perspective of my personal/work needs in which I found efficiency. Thank you, AMD! 👌🏼🧐🎈

I sincerely hope that your company will develop
I hope that you will ultimately reach a point where you can satisfy the average PC game demand with just the CPU

This is one of the most unique places in the world, and these days, $599 is not cheap for ordinary consumers like me

It is a price set lower than that bad company, but I think that is not enough, so I am making this offer, so please watch it to the end and make a decision

A company that uses a very bad method to deceive consumers
Some people call it a luxury strategy, but that is a mistake

I don't know your past well, and I don't want to search to find out and be disappointed again

How about working with more than 70% of ordinary consumers right now

I would like to make the following offer

This is a place where energy flows dynamically to the point that there is a saying that if it works in the Korean market, it works in the world

If you can increase your market share to 40% or more in the Korean market, RADEON can immediately move on to the next stage. It is possible

You also know the importance of marketing

What is attractive marketing?
Marketing that suits the situation
Marketing that suits the time

How about holding a 1+1 event every week that lives up to the name 9070?

Starting from the day of release,

Select 7 people every 9 days and give them the right to get one more of the same model if they buy one

will be full of really fun and enjoyable things

comments.text:
The price ($599) is AMAZING.  I calculated the incremental cost between 7800xt and 9070xt.  The chip is $80 more to make @TSMC vs 7800xt.  It's 8% bigger, the N4 process is 11% more expensive, and yields at the start of volume production are 70% typically - Not 90% like 7800xt at the end! of life.  I put this into a VLSI calculator and got $80 higher costs.   The 9070xt needs 20% more power and cooling which i estimate at $20 in cost.  Add in $17 for markups (AIB - 12%, retailers - 5%).  So the entire GPU costs $117 more than the 7800xt to make - AMD IS TAKING NO PROFITS on the last $120 of cost on this board!!  This product is an NVidia killer at an AWESOME price!

LETS ALL BUY 5M CARDS SO RADEON GETS HEALTHY AGAIN!!!

comments.text:
I bought the 7900 XTX red devil graphics card the day it came out, I still use it with incredible pleasure and its performance is currently at the level of 5080 with pure muscle power, and even surpasses 4090 due to your special work with COD games. So I thank you for your efforts.

Yes, there are many people who play games by turning on ray-tracing nowadays, but there are also many people like me who value raw power over pure power. We never use RTX to reduce input lag in competitive games. Many people don't care about RTX for fake frames produced with multi frame gen and a little light show.

Why didn't you design another flagship model with high VRAM? Why didn't you make the current predecessor of 7900 XTX when you invested so much in development for RTX and machine learning?

As someone who has been using the AMD ecosystem for years, I expected you to release another model like 9090XTX. Even the cards you released 2 years ago have more VRAM.

Yes, you targeted the middle segment where competition is most intense in the market, and of course I understand that the reason for this is due to commercial gains, but I don't understand why you didn't launch a predator against the 5090.

Why didn't you care so much about the graphics card section when you dominated the processor market so much and released dozens of new models?

comments.text: AMD has a bit of a problem here. Both versions are based on the same 357mm2 die of TSMC N4. The 5070Ti is a cut down 378mm2 die, so Nvidia will much prefer to make 5080s out of it. The 5070 is an uncut 263mm2 die that Nvidia can pump out in massive quantities. And the 9070 is a 16GB card vs the 12GB of the 5070. AMD really do not want to artificially cut down XTs to non-XTs. They want prospective 5070 to pay the $50 and get 16GB and 9070XT/5070Ti performance.... And it's going to work, because the 5070 was announced pre-import-tax announcement. So it's going to be $600 on the street. That makes it "With AMD you get an entire performance tier and 16GB for the equivalent price of a 5070".

comments.text:
I've only stuck with NVIDIA for the past 20+ years. I remember way back when I had an ATI card and how much trouble I had with the drivers. Blue screen, completely frozen screen and random crashes while gaming. I had problems just installing the driver.
When the 7900xtx was released, I took the chance again and thought they had now had time to grow and many years to improve. 
I really don't regret this. I am EXTREMELY happy with my 7900xtx card which has a USB-C port on the GPU itself and I connect my VR headset directly to the video card and it runs smoothly. AMD (adrenaline) have become absolutely flawless now and I haven't had any trouble at all. WONDERFUL work AMD. 
I was all NVIDIA for over 20 years, but now that's all over and I'll continue to support AMD. I have a "toaster" as a PC and NVIDIA's cards are GIGANTIC, but AMD's reference cards are compact brutes and fit even in mini itx cabinets.
We don't want an NVIDIA monopoly on video cards, because this will only hurt ourselves and NVIDIA can only continue with bloody prices. 
Competition is good for :
-the customer
-price war
-design options

Now I'm all AMD and I'm here to stay.😍

@mountaink2z  You're still running damage control I see. You say "AMD are 100% on a loss on this GPU". Do you have any actual proof or are you just talking out of your behind ?
Polaris was on 14nm and was ~232mm2 at around $250. RDNA1 was on 7nm and was ~251mm2 at around $400 (already nearly double Polaris). 
7nm wasn't double the cost of 14, ESPECIALLY at high yields which a small die like that would've had on a mature process node !
Now we get this garbo on 4nm around ~351mm2 WITH AI SLOP taking up die space, and yet SOMEHOW this is supposed to be ok ?
What's the yield on this die size on 4nm, what's the wafer cost and how does it compare to previous gens ? 
Again, DO YOU HAVE SOME COLD HARD NUMBERS, or do you just like claiming that "AMD are 100% on a loss on this GPU" ? Good guy AMD huh ? 
The same "GOOD GUY AMD" who forgot what made them what they are in the first place and now are content with offering just "slightly better value" than the OBSCENITY Nvidia is charging, man we're lucky to have 'em, eh ?! comments.text:
​ @mountaink2z  Finally, all this is coming from someone who's had AMD EVEN IN THE FX DAYS !
I've had multiple Athlon 64x2s, I've had an FX 6100, I've had an R5 2600X, I've had an R7 3700X, I now have a 5800x3d.
I've had a Radeon HD 6850, I've had an R9 380, I've had multiple R9 290Xs, I've had an RX 580, I've had a Vega56, I now have a 5700XT !
I have a laptop with a an R5 4600H, I've had a Mini PC with an R7 5800H, I have another laptop with an R5 2500u !
I'm not BY ANY MEANS an "AMD hater" or "Nvidia shill" or anything of the sort ! I've supported this company THROUGHOUT ! 
That's mostly because I found GREAT VALUE in the things I purchased, at the time I purchased them, for the use cases I had at that time, but what they're doing and what they're becoming is something I'm no longer comfortable with ! In ABSOLUTE TERMS, I no longer find GREAT VALUE. People keep talking in relative terms; relative to Nvidia though...
And I believe I'm not the only one in this position either !

comments.text: @ maybe not this or even in the next two gens but think about it like this. NVIDIA was a multi billion dollar corporation like AMD is now. They got into the right thing and catapulted. I still think NVIDIA’s stock is way too overvalued but the market doesn’t just yet. I could be wrong. The evidence I provide is Ryzen taking market share from intel. It was a long 1 2 combo. AMD struck when intel was complacent (1) and offered a strong hit with Ryzen (2) and hit them hard enough to take market share. Threadripper also helped. Now intel is making their own mistakes all dazed up that they don’t need AMD to hit them anymore. Nobody could’ve guessed this shift by the evidence we had then. Anybody that did was hopefully speculating. Nvidia is having one of their worse launches ever in terms of brand and consumer perception (1) and AMD needs to get enough jabs in there to take points away (the possible 2) so yes, I absolutely do think that if AMD uses their money and invests into R&D and gets their stuff together like they did with Ryzen, they can catch up. Can they beat them? Idk, we weren’t here thinking intel would be losing a lot of ground to AMD so I think only a fool would answer that definitively and only a fool would say “no” with a straight face when presented with the last decade. I don’t see them beating them in one or two gens but give them a few years with enough time and money and focus and I think they will. Call me a fool but AMD hasn’t given us any actual reason to think they CANT do it. Look at the console market and how consoles are actually competent, the mobile PC market with all them mobile processors and their industrial side as well as laptops. They’re a very well all around business and I think it’s coming.

comments.text: @lacm81  FSR2/3 is an algorithm-based upscaling technique. While it’s not simple, it uses mathematical formulations to determine pixel colors by analyzing surrounding pixels and motion data. Since it relies purely on math, it runs on standard shaders, making it compatible with most GPUs. But it's also the biggest weakness of it. It's potential is limited and probably FSR3.1 is already made it there.

comments.text:
@SahariyarAhad  AMD claimed that fast RAM would easily work with the 7000 and 9000 series. At launch, that was definitely not a reality. Compatibility issues eased with updates, but it was a mess early on.
AMD claimed that the Ryzen 5000 "XT" series was competitive with CPUs on more advanced processes and architectures. They misrepresented the products with slides using a midrange GPU, to minimize the differences between products.
When FSR was first released, they marketed it as a direct competitor to DLSS, despite it falling short in some respects.
I'm not carrying out a witch hunt, and I'm not going to unearth decades-old controversy. Just pointing out that it's pretty uncommon for AMD to release honest marketing. Their competitors are no better, but AMD are not generally honest.

comments.text: ​ @alancarr195  It probably has to do with the yields. They buy whole chip wafers at a set cost from TSMC which they then divide. Some parts of the wafer are inevitably worse or better due to the silicon lottery. If a large amount of pieces are able to perform at top tier levels, then they can sell more of the set cost wafer at a higher price. Therefore, they can bring the cost down for the lower yields. If yield percentages aren't as ideal, they have to increase the cost of lower tiers because they make up the bulk of the yields from the wafer.
